messages.message:
(Yi-Chin Lee/Houston Chronicle via AP)HOUSTON (AP) — Power was expected to be restored by late Wednesday to nearly all Houston area homes and businesses left in the dark by last week’s deadly storm, according to officials.
I would also like to recognize the patience of our customers,” Tutunjian said.
The Houston area was expected to have potentially dangerous heat this weekend, with temperatures and humidity levels higher than normal for May, according to the National Weather Service.
The deadly storm took place as the Houston area and several Texas counties to the north were still recovering from flooding caused by heavy rainfall in late April and early May.
Houston City Council Member Abbie Kamin said last week’s storm should prompt discussion about fortifying power lines and other infrastructure in Houston.

Most in Houston area are getting power back after storm, but some may have to wait until the weekendMost in Houston area are getting power back after storm, but some may have to wait until the weekend View PhotoHOUSTON (AP) — Power was expected to be restored by late Wednesday to nearly all Houston area homes and businesses left in the dark by last week’s deadly storm, according to officials.
The storm spawned two tornadoes — one near the northwest Houston suburb of Cypress and the other in Waller County, located northwest of Houston.
The Houston area was expected to have potentially dangerous heat this weekend, with temperatures and humidity levels higher than normal for May, according to the National Weather Service.
The deadly storm took place as the Houston area and several Texas counties to the north were still recovering from flooding caused by heavy rainfall in late April and early May.
Houston City Council Member Abbie Kamin said last week’s storm should prompt discussion about fortifying power lines and other infrastructure in Houston.

Unhappy Xcel Energy customers in Boulder, Colorado spoke their mind last month in a virtual hearing put on by the state's utility commission.
On April 6, the utility shut off power to 55,000 customers during an intense wind storm in hopes of preventing the sparking of a wildfire by downed lines.
Though it has its critics, this strategy is being adopted across the Western United States as a tool in the toolbox when it comes to preventing wildfires.
And we need to do everything we can within our control to lessen the chance of a wildfire ignition," he said.
"With time, with experience and with investment, we're gonna get better at using this as a solution to mitigate wildfire risk," said Sioshansi.

Unhappy Xcel Energy customers in Boulder, Colorado spoke their mind last month in a virtual hearing put on by the state's utility commission.
On April 6, the utility shut off power to 55,000 customers during an intense wind storm in hopes of preventing the sparking of a wildfire by downed lines.
Though it has its critics, this strategy is being adopted across the Western United States as a tool in the toolbox when it comes to preventing wildfires.
And we need to do everything we can within our control to lessen the chance of a wildfire ignition," he said.
"With time, with experience and with investment, we're gonna get better at using this as a solution to mitigate wildfire risk," said Sioshansi.

Powerline-caused wildfires are getting a closer look from Montana state lawmakers less than eight months before the next legislative session.
The Central Montana Railroad sued NorthWestern in 2023, attempting to recover costs for destroyed machinery and infrastructure burned by the fire.
The Denton fire wasn’t mentioned during the first half of the Energy and Telecommunication Interim Committee, which concerned wildfire liability.
The wildfires caused by utilities are a national issue, said Mark Lambrecht, of Montana Rural Electric Cooperatives.
Chris Pope, a Democratic Senator from Bozeman, recalled that at an earlier meeting NorthWestern characterized wildfire policy as a high priority.

At least four people have died, and at least 35 have been injured after a tornado swept through Iowa.
The central and northern parts of Iowa first received about 2 to 4 inches of rain Tuesday, causing flash flooding.
Flood advisories are active in the area until Friday, the weather service said.
One to 3 inches of rain are forecasted in that area, according to the weather service.
The National Weather Service is encouraging people not to toss lit cigarettes on the ground, engage in activities with open flames, drive on a flat tire or park their vehicles in dry grass.

The Quarter Freezer TrickThis technique is often referred to as the Quarter Freezer, an oldie but goodie that has saved many a fridge-full of food from spoilage after storms or heavy snowfall.
Curious about why one would place a coin atop a frozen water cup in their freezer?
For those who forget easily, you can employ this trick immediately and leave the cup in your freezer, ready for the next storm.
Canva Canva loading...How Virginia Residents Could Use This Trick:When a power outage occurs, we often avoid opening the freezer to prevent food spoilage.
This way, you can estimate the safety of your frozen food.

The official start of what is likely to be an active Atlantic hurricane season is almost here.
Federal forecasters joined the chorus of expert voices calling for a hyperactive Atlantic hurricane season when NOAA’s National Hurricane Center released its official preseason forecast Thursday.
This is the most aggressive preseason forecast issued for NOAA’s hurricane season outlook.
The region is often more vulnerable to flooding in the early part of hurricane season and that’s particularly the case this year, Keim explained.
A named tropical storm or hurricane has formed in either May or early June in every hurricane season since 2015.

CNN —The official start of what is likely to be an active Atlantic hurricane season is almost here.
Federal forecasters joined the chorus of expert voices calling for a hyperactive Atlantic hurricane season when NOAA’s National Hurricane Center released its official preseason forecast Thursday.
This is the most aggressive preseason forecast issued for NOAA’s hurricane season outlook.
The region is often more vulnerable to flooding in the early part of hurricane season and that’s particularly the case this year, Keim explained.
A named tropical storm or hurricane has formed in either May or early June in every hurricane season since 2015.

9e656eed-465e-4f45-ab77-2cd041e90260.location: With the information given, it is not possible to determine a specific location for the main event.

messages.message:
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) has released its official outlook for the upcoming Atlantic hurricane season.
Forecasters anticipate an 85% chance for an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season in 2024.
Here's an early look at what to expect for the upcoming season.
Early PredictionThe NOAA outlook on the upcoming Atlantic hurricane season is strictly only an outlook on the number of storms to expect.
It's important to remember to stay weather aware during hurricane season since it only takes one landfalling hurricane to cause catastrophic damage.

There could be 25 named storms during the 2024 Atlantic hurricane season — the most federal forecasters have ever predicted and a warning shot for South Carolina and other Southeastern states.
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted an above-normal hurricane season on Thursday, with between 17 and 25 total named storms.
The record number of storms predicted by NOAA in a preseason outlook had previously been 14 to 23 named storms in 2010.
NOAA hurricane prediction breakdownThe 2024 hurricane season forecast calls for an 85% chance of an above-normal season, a 10% chance of a near-normal season and a 5% chance of a below-normal season.
A breakdown of NOAA’s predictions for Atlantic hurricane season 2024.

Get ready for what nearly all the experts think will be one of the busiest Atlantic hurricane seasons on record, thanks to unprecedented ocean heat and a brewing La Nina.
An average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms — seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.
A La Nina tends to turbocharge Atlantic storm activity while depressing storminess in the Pacific, and an El Nino does the opposite.
La Nina usually reduces high-altitude winds that can decapitate hurricanes, and generally during a La Nina there's more instability or storminess in the atmosphere, which can seed hurricane development.
Instead of a La Nina, there was a strong El Nino, which usually inhibits storminess a bit.

Dangerous brew: Ocean heat and La Nina combo likely mean more Atlantic hurricanes this summerWASHINGTON (AP) — Get ready for what nearly all the experts think will be one of the busiest Atlantic hurricane seasons on record, thanks to unprecedented ocean heat and a brewing La Nina.
An average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.
A La Nina tends to turbocharge Atlantic storm activity while depressing storminess in the Pacific and an El Nino does the opposite.
La Nina usually reduces high-altitude winds that can decapitate hurricanes, and generally during a La Nina there's more instability or storminess in the atmosphere, which can seed hurricane development.
Instead of a La Nina, there was a strong El Nino, which usually inhibits storminess a bit.

Nearly all the experts think 2024 will be one of the busiest Atlantic hurricane seasons on record.
Recommended VideosAn average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.
La Nina usually reduces high-altitude winds that can decapitate hurricanes, and generally during a La Nina there's more instability or storminess in the atmosphere, which can seed hurricane development.
Peak hurricane season usually is mid-August to mid-October with the official season starting June 1 and ending Nov. 30.
Instead of a La Nina, there was a strong El Nino, which usually inhibits storminess a bit.

An average Atlantic hurricane season produces 14 named storms, seven of them hurricanes and three major hurricanes.
A La Nina tends to turbocharge Atlantic storm activity while depressing storminess in the Pacific and an El Nino does the opposite.

messages.message:
The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration is predicting an "above-normal" 2024 Atlantic hurricane season, releasing its highest ever pre-season annual forecast on Thursday.
This is the highest named storm forecast NOAA has ever issued in May.
Considering an average season consists of 14 named storms, 7 hurricanes and 3 major hurricanes, this is a statement forecast.
This year, La Niña is forecast (77% likelihood) to settle in and coincide with the peak of hurricane season.
And when you combine that with what’s certain to be a La Niña, no one has seen this before," McNoldy said.

And when you combine that with what’s certain to be a La Niña, no one has seen this before," McNoldy said.

messages.message:
While the conditions are not favorable for development as it moves to the northeast, NOAA forecasters are confident this is just the beginning.
It's forecasting between 17 to 25 total named storms (winds of 39 mph or higher).
This is the greatest number of storms predicted in NOAA's May forecast.
The previous highest was in 2010 when they called for 14-23 named storms, 8-14 hurricanes, and 3-7 majors.
This afternoon Miami-Dade's Mayor will join the Emergency Management Director to stress the importance of staying vigilant for not only hurricane season, potentially flooding and extreme heat.

As Sunday's severe weather threat brews, the National Weather Service could lower the threat level or even raise it.
National Weather Service National Weather Service loading...Get our free mobile appHere's the current Hazarous Weather Outlook from the National Weather Service as it stands right now:Daily chances of thunderstorms are forecast through Monday.
Severe storms cannot be ruled out any day, but the best chance of severe storms is still on Sunday.
The National Weather Service has some tips on how to prepare your Memorial Day Weekend celebrations.

The severe weather turned south Wednesday after a deadly tornado wreaked havoc in the small city of the day before.
Severe weather storms moved through Wednesday night.
Belton police said the severe weather caused several roads throughout town to become impassible due to fallen trees and flooding.
The National Weather Service of Fort Worth plans to conduct a storm survey to assess the extent of the damages from this storm.
On Tuesday alone, the National Weather Service said it received 23 tornado reports, with 21 in Iowa.

articleThe U.S. Department of Agriculture approved emergency financial relief for struggling crawfish farmers and fisherman for a 2024 harvest that is down 50-90% across Louisiana, according to the Louisiana State University Agricultural Center .
Crawfish season is winding down across Louisiana , which produces about the majority of the nation's crawfish every year, according to the Louisiana Crawfish Promotion and Research Board .
SALT WATER THREATENS LOUISIANA DRINKING WATER SUPPLY AMID MISSISSIPPI RIVER DROUGHTFile: The sun sets over a field with crawfish traps near Crowley.
(Jon Shapley/Houston Chronicle / Getty Images)The Ag center estimated the potential losses to be about $140 million to the state's $230 million a year crawfish industry.
The crawfish industry needs all the support it can get right now."
